captions.text:
A Letter to My Mother
- Lee woo-geun

Mother,
I killed people.

I threw an explosive weapon called a
hand grenade, killing them in an instant.
Mother,

the arms and legs of the enemy
soldiers were blown off.

They are our enemies, but the fact
that they are also people like us,

and that we even share
the same blood with them,
makes my heart heavy.

Mother,
what is this war for?

I have to tell you these complicated
and painful feelings
to make myself calm down.

A terrible thought
came into my mind.

Now a number of students lie with
their faces down under a scorching sun,

waiting for enemy forces
as if they are waiting for death.
There are too many enemy soldiers.
We are only seventy one.
I'm afraid of what will happen.
Yesterday, I washed my underclothes.
But I do not know why

I was thinking of a shroud
when I changed into them.

What I mean by shroud is
the cloth used for the dead.

Mother,
I might die today.

The enemy soldiers are
not likely to retreat.

Mother,
what I'm afraid of is not death,

but the fact that I might not be able
to see you or my brothers again.

But I will survive.
I will return alive.

Mother, now I can
finally calm down.

Mother, I will return
alive to meet you.

I want to eat
lettuce-wrapped rice.

I want to drink cold water
that will make my teeth ache.
Oh, they are coming.

Mother, good-bye,
good-bye.

No, not good-bye
I'll continue to write.

Lee woo-geun, a student soldier of
the 3rd Division in the armed forces
died in battle on August 10, 1950.

And a letter was found in the
pocket of his military uniform.

title: EBS 클립뱅크(Clipbank) - 한국전쟁의 참상(Tragedy of the Korean War)
